message: The first action taken by the Republican majority in the new Congress—in a closed door meeting late last night—was to gut the independent Office of Congressional Ethics. The midnight move will put the independent watchdog under the control of the House Ethics Committee, and prohibits it from hiring a spokesperson, contacting law enforcement without approval, or investigating anonymous tips. Hardly draining the swamp. I will oppose this on House floor today.

I just returned from the House floor where I took the oath of office to represent Vermonters in the House of Representatives for the next two years. I am grateful to Vermonters for this opportunity and am ready to get to work. - Peter
Humbled and honored that Vermonters have allowed me to represent them in Congress. Ready to get to work! – Peter

Yesterday I introduced my first bill of the 115th Congress, the Medicare Prescription Drug Price Negotiation Act. Putting the federal government's purchasing power to work to save seniors and the taxpayer money is simply common sense. The fact that we continue to pay retail rates for wholesale purchases is ridiculous. It's long past time we put an end this sweetheart deal for big Pharma.  If President-elect Donald J. Trump was serious about this campaign promise, I will work with him to make it happen. – Peter

On January 20, Donald J. Trump will take the oath of office to become the 45th President of the United States. He will raise his right hand and swear to ‘preserve, protect and defend the Constitution of the United States.’ The American people should have every confidence that he will follow through on this solemn oath and act in the country’s best interest rather than his own. Senator Ben Cardin and I introduced a resolution demanding that he abide by the Constitution and sever business ties so that conflicts of interest are eliminated on Day 1. – Peter
NA

During the winter months, VTrans plow crews work long hours keeping our roads clear so we can safely get where we need to go. Check out their new Winter Central web portal that will help us navigate Vermont’s winter road conditions. It includes a new Plow Finder feature showing the location of all 250 VTrans plow trucks in near real-time so you can track when the next one is coming and plan your trip accordingly. Thank you VTrans plow crews for your often exhausting and often dangerous work keeping the roads clear all winter long!

Today, President-elect Donald J. Trump strongly endorsed an issue I have been pushing hard for in Congress – requiring the federal government to use its significant bulk purchasing power to cut the price of prescription drugs for seniors and taxpayers.  Here is what he said at this morning’s press conference:   “We're the largest buyer of drugs in the world. And yet we don't bid properly. We're going to start bidding. We're going to save billions of dollars over a period of time.”   Music to my ears. It’s crazy that Medicare buys drugs at wholesale but pays retail prices. I’ve introduced a bill that would require price negotiations with Big Pharma. It will cut drug prices, save taxpayer dollars, and shore up the Medicare trust fund. I’m ready to get to work with President-elect Trump to pass this commonsense legislation.

It’s about time that Volkswagen executives admitted to criminal wrongdoing and face the consequences for knowingly deceiving hundreds of thousands of American consumers, including some 3,000 Vermonters. They cheated on emissions rules that protect our environment and violated the trust placed in them by their customers. I am pleased to see the company and those responsible for the crimes finally being brought to justice.

Ahead of House vote today to repeal the Affordable Care Act, Peter took to the House floor to call out the House majority for repealing a law that has benefited thousands of Vermonters with no replacement law in sight.  “Bottom line, you’re the majority in the House, you’re the majority in the Senate, you’ve got the presidency. You’ve got some responsibility to show us the beef. Where is the plan? Now there’s a lot of paper over there, but you haven’t shown us a plan and here’s why: because when you put pen to paper, all hell is going to break loose on your side, because you have to move beyond the rhetoric to figuring out how you’re going to pay to keep our kids on our healthcare plan, you’re going to have to figure out how to pay if we’re going to let folks with preexisting conditions have healthcare. Those don’t solve themselves, and you don’t have a plan.”

I was sickened by President-elect Donald Trump’s comments belittling the record of civil rights icon, Rep. John Lewis. John is a personal hero of mine and many other Americans. His storied career defines leadership, courage, civility, and action. I am deeply disappointed that Mr. Trump is continuing the invective of his campaign into his presidency.    Over the weekend and today, I’ve heard from a number of Vermonters asking me not to attend Friday’s inauguration. As I outlined on this page earlier this month, I will not do anything to normalize Mr. Trump’s rhetoric or his demeaning treatment of individuals or whole classes of people. And I will fiercely oppose any effort on his part to take away or limit the civil rights of any American.    However, I believe the inaugural ceremony is about more than any individual. It is about the peaceful transition of power enshrined in our Constitution. I believe it is my job to participate in, and be a witness to, this touchstone of our democracy and powerful symbol to the world. So, while I respect the decision of some of my colleagues to stay home, I will attend, but not celebrate, Friday’s ceremony.

Disregarding the fact that 2016 was the hottest on record, President Trump today doubled down on his head-in-the sand climate change denial. Tar sands are the dirtiest of dirty energy sources. Clean energy policies protect the environment AND create good jobs. Bill McKibben and 350.org got it right: This is not a done deal. #noDAPL #noKXL

Later today, the House majority will yet again try to limit women’s reproductive rights. This time, they want to make permanent the discriminatory Hyde Amendment and raise taxes on small businesses providing employees with health insurance that covers reproductive health services. I will vote NO on this bill and any other assault on women’s rights and health care. – Peter

Yesterday, I met with the Syrian families who have arrived in their new home, Rutland. They were warm, solid, generous people doing whatever it takes to give their children a better chance at life. I wish Donald Trump had been there with me to meet those families and meet the people of Rutland. I think he would come to a different decision. – Peter

Steve Bannon should not be permitted to pass through the White House gates let alone serve as a permanent member of the National Security Council. His appointment to the NSC is dangerous, unprecedented and misguided. David Axelrod and Karl Rove were banned from regularly participating in NSC meetings by Presidents Obama and Bush. There should be no seat at the national security table for partisan politics, especially the brand promoted by Bannon in his previous job -- fringe conspiracy theories, the alt-right movement, anti-Semitism, racism, sexism, and homophobia.

This morning Peter was joined by ACLU-Vermont at a Burlington press conference to denounce orders by President Donald J. Trump to ban refugees and some migrants from admission to the United States.  "I have never seen an action by the President of the United States as damaging to the tradition of religious liberty and open acceptance of people seeking asylum as this immigration order by President Trump,” Peter said. “We've got to resist this, and we've got to reverse it."  Watch the full press conference below via the Burlington Free Press.
Happening today LIVE at NOON: Watch Peter bring the story of Rutland's refugees to the House floor.

“Prescription drugs are lifesaving and pain relieving but they’re killing us with their skyrocketing prices. Our patients are getting hammered and our hospitals are getting squeezed. If we don’t take common sense steps, we’re going to collapse under the weight of prescription drug prices that nobody can pay.” – Peter  At a roundtable discussion at the Community Health Centers of Burlington this week, Peter laid out his four point plan for making prescription drug prices more affordable for consumers, taxpayers, and businesses. You can read about it in detail here: https://welch.house.gov/media-center/press-releases/welch-unveils-four-point-prescription-drug-affordability-agenda.

Peter will be LIVE on Vermont Public Radio's Vermont Edition today at noon to talk about his priorities for the new Congress and President Trump's recent executive orders. You can listen in and ask him a question by following the link below.
“Injustice anywhere is a threat to justice everywhere” – MLK, Jr.   I am holding these wise words dear as we enter Black History Month. – Peter

It’s really important when a Vermonter contacts me. That matters to us. I think it activates in the individual a sense that they can act in general. So this call to me may be incidental, but then they may go to that march in Montpelier. They may decide to run for the local select board. It may be that step they needed to say, 'I’m going to join the school board.’  So act, act, act. We have to do that. That’s the obligation of all of us who care about our democracy. – Peter  Catch Peter’s full interview from yesterday on Vermont Public Radio’s Vermont Edition below.

A free and open internet is critical to innovation, entrepreneurship, and consumers living in a digital age. The Federal Communications Commission should not undermine #NetNeutrality by rolling back rules prohibiting unfair internet “fast lines.”

It's fantastic to see Switchback Brewing Company join the ranks of other great employee-owned businesses in Vermont like King Arthur Flour and Gardener's Supply Garden Centers. Bill Cherry and his team at Switchback were brewing pioneers who played a big part in earning Vermont's beer industry the world-renowned reputation it now enjoys. It is good to know that their vision for brewing awesome beer will continue to be carried on by Vermonters right here in the Green Mountain State. Cheers!
Hope everyone has a chance to get outside and enjoy the fresh snow!
Join Peter this Thursday at 5:30 p.m. right here on his page for a Facebook Town Hall. He'll be at his computer answering your questions live.

Join Peter right here for a Facebook town hall tomorrow at 5:30 p.m. He’ll be at his computer answering your questions about his agenda in the new Congress, what’s happening in Washington, and the news of the day.

ICYMI: Starting at 5:30 PM this evening, Peter will be at his computer answering your questions about his agenda and what's going on in D.C. Check back here on his page at 5:30 to participate. The Q&A will last for an hour.
Today Peter went to the House floor to demand an investigation of President Donald J. Trump's ties to Russia.

I can't type as quick as I'd like, but I'll be here until 6:30 to answer as many questions as I can! Ask away!  Update, Thx everyone.. I really enjoyed this. Tumultuous times and we all have to hang in. Sorry I cant type faster  Sorry I missed ansering so many good questions. We will do this again soon Peter

President Donald J. Trump says transgender rights should be decided by 50 states. Wrong again, Mr. President. You have a moral and legal obligation to protect the rights of ALL Americans regardless of where they live, especially children. These vulnerable kids face discrimination, bullying and harassment every day as they struggle with their gender identity.  You just made their struggle a lot more difficult. Shame on you. – Peter

A warm welcome home to the men and women of the Vermont Air National Guard (Official) after a successful deployment in the Middle East. I know I join all Vermonters in thanking you for your service, and thanking your families and employers for filling in while you were serving our nation. Thank you. – Peter

In just over a month in office President Donald J. Trump has approved a special operations raid in Yemen that killed Yemeni women and children and resulted in the death of Chief Petty Officer William Owens. Trump administration officials have signaled that it may soon send additional U.S. troops into northern Syria to join the special operations forces already there. We can debate whether these actions are prudent and effective, but that debate should happen in the halls of Congress. Under the U.S. Constitution, it is the responsibility of Congress to authorize the use of military force -- and it is long overdue for Congress to step up and do its job. That's why I joined Congressman Jim McGovern and 17 bipartisan colleagues urging Speaker Paul Ryan to allow for debate and a vote on a new AUMF to address the fight against ISIS and al-Qaeda affiliates in the Middle East.

This Friday I’ll be hosting a Congress in Your Community town hall from 5:30 to 6:30 p.m. at the Briggs Opera House A Community Arts Center in White River Junction. I want to hear your hopes and concerns for the new Congress and Administration. Hope you can stop by!  WHAT: Congress in Your Community town hall with Peter WHEN: Friday, March 3rd, 5:30 – 6:30 p.m. WHERE: The Briggs Opera House, 5 South Main Street, White River Junction

Tonight President Trump delivered a speech soft in tone but steeped in the all too familiar hard-edged policy agenda of his campaign.  He proposes the repeal of the Affordable Care Act with no credible plan to replace it.  He wants to build a wall on our southern border that is not necessary nor will it be effective.  His budget and tax proposals will dramatically increase the deficit and income inequality while shifting an enormous financial burden to Vermont and other states.  And he wants to dramatically increase a bloated Pentagon budget at the expense of working Americans, hospitals, seniors, college students, and the middle class. While I hope to find common ground with him on rebuilding the nation's infrastructure and cutting the cost of prescription drugs, I believe his actions going forward will speak louder than his words tonight.  --Peter

Catch Peter live on Vermont Public Radio's Vermont Edition today at noon. He'll be joined by his special guest from the President’s speech last night, Ahmed Alsaeedi of Burlington. Ahmed served as an interpreter for the U.S. Army on the Iraq battlefield. He was then marked for assassination in Iraq for helping our Army and fled under the U.S. Special Immigrant Visa program. He now helps other refugees fleeing war transition to their new lives in Vermont.  Had Ahmed been abroad when President Trump issued his extreme vetting executive order, he would not have been allowed to return to Burlington even though he is a legal resident and risked his life to help our soldiers. Hope you will tune in to hear his story.

Ahmed Alsaeedi of Burlington joined me last night in the House chamber to hear President Donald J. Trump’s speech to Congress. He served as an interpreter for the U.S. Army in Iraq from 2007-2011. In doing so, he risked his life and was marked for assassination because he helped American soldiers. Ahmed fled to Vermont in 2012 through the U.S. Special Immigrant Visa program. He now helps refugees fleeing violence and war around the world adjust to their new lives in Vermont. Thank you, Ahmed, for your service to our country in Iraq and to refugees here at home. – Peter

Attorney General Sessions, while under oath, at best misled the Senate Judiciary Committee about his contacts with Russian officials. At worst, he committed perjury. He can no longer serve as America’s chief law enforcement officer, let alone oversee an investigation into Trump campaign officials' contacts with Russians during the election. He should resign from office immediately. – Peter

Tomorrow, I’ll be hosting a Congress in Your Community event from 5:00 to 5:45 p.m. at The Elm Street Market Bennington. I want to hear your hopes and concerns for the new Congress and Administration. Hope you can stop by!  WHAT: Congress in Your Community town hall with Peter WHEN: Monday, March 6th, 5:00 – 5:45 p.m. WHERE: The Elm Street Market, 251 Elm Street
Happy 226th birthday, Vermont! Our brave little state entered the Union on this day in 1791 and has been punching above our weight ever since.

If you put lipstick on a pig, it’s still a pig. President Trump made it clear during the campaign that he intended to ban Muslims from entering our country. Doing so would be patently unconstitutional and make America less safe, not more. To defeat ISIS, we need cooperation from the Muslim community here and around the world. And we should honor not retreat from our longstanding tradition of welcoming refugees fleeing war and violence around the world. The courts struck down the President’s first executive order and I expect they will weigh in again on this more tailored version. – Peter

Town Meeting Day represents the best tradition of how we do business in Vermont: We listen to one another, respect different opinions, and get the job done with common sense solutions. I hope all Vermonters carry on this important act of civic engagement this year by attending Town Meeting, voicing your opinion and voting on local issues. – Peter  (Painting is Norman Rockwell’s “Freedom of Speech,” depicting a Town Meeting in Arlington, Vermont in 1942.)
Today in the House Committee on Energy and Commerce, Peter slammed GOP leaders' so-called “repeal and replace” bill. Watch it below.

At the start of the 26th straight hour of debate on GOP Leadership’s so-called “repeal and replace” healthcare legislation, Peter stepped out of the House Committee on Energy and Commerce hearing to share his thoughts.  “We are going to keep up the fight. We are going to keep healthcare and make it more accessible for Americans. I pledge my best effort to you to do that.” – Peter

At about 2 a.m. this morning, during an all-night debate on a measure to repeal the Affordable Care Act, Peter called out Republican leaders for attempting to destroy Planned Parenthood by cutting off its funding.

Calling all college students interested in public service and the legislative process! An internship in Peter’s Vermont or Washington, D.C. offices is a great way to gain valuable experience and college credit. We are taking applications for our summer internship program now and the application deadline is fast approaching. Click below for more info on how to apply!

It’s now clear why House GOP leaders last week rammed through committee their so-called “repeal and replace” healthcare bill without a single public hearing. The non-partisan Congressional Budget Office just announced 24 million Americans will lose health coverage. That’s right, 24 million Americans will lose the peace of mind that comes with health care coverage. They can no longer hide the ball. This fight is not over.

Many thanks to the Vermont State Police, county sheriffs, local police, first responders, utility line workers, VTrans plow crews, and all those who have worked tirelessly to keep our roads clear and Vermonters safe. Thanks for all you do! – Peter

You can tell the values of any president by examining his budget.  President Trump’s budget sends a clear message: You are on your own. It doubles down on Pentagon spending at the expense of the middle class, vulnerable families, seniors, clean air and water, scientific research, diplomacy and the arts. President Trump calls it his ‘America First’ budget. I call it an ‘Americans last’ budget. Like the budgets of his predecessors, this one is dead on arrival.  Congress will write the budget, not President Trump. – Peter

See what the The Times Argus/Rutland Herald had to say about Peter’s effort to defeat the Trump/Ryan health care bill which will cause some 60,000 Vermonters to lose health coverage, gut Vermont’s community hospitals, dramatically raise health care costs for Vermonters approaching retirement, and give a huge tax cut to the 400 wealthiest families in America.

"This country since Harry Truman has had an elusive but desirable goal: healthcare for all our citizens. We've made two strides. One, in 1964 with the passage of Medicare. Another in 2010 with the passage of Obamacare. We should be moving towards Medicare for all our citizens. Instead, this bill does not move forward. It goes backward."
What you have is not a healthcare bill. You have a tax cut bill masquerading as a healthcare bill. – Peter

I am relieved that the Trump-Ryan so-called "repeal and replace" bill will never see the light of day. It failed today because it was unmasked for what it really was: a massive tax cut for the wealthiest Americans disguised as health care reform. To pay for it, 24 million Americans would have lost their healthcare, Vermont’s community hospitals would have taken an enormous financial hit, and premiums for working seniors would have soared. I hope the ashes of this bill will lead to a collaborative effort to make health care more affordable and accessible for every American. It’s time to roll up our sleeves and improve the Affordable Care Act. --Peter

Tomorrow, Peter will vote against President Donald J. Trump’s effort to gut federal privacy rules that require internet service providers to obtain consent from consumers before sharing their Web browsing and app usage history with marketers. You have a right to expect privacy when using the internet.
Thanks to everyone who joined Senator Leahy, Senator Sanders, and me this weekend in Hardwick. It was great to see so many Vermonters. It’s really important to stay engaged! – Peter

President Trump believes we either have jobs or a clean environment. He has it exactly wrong. We have both or we have neither. A confident nation faces its problems – it doesn’t deny them. President Trump should keep the Clean Power Plan intact and face the realities of a warming world.

This Friday I’ll be hosting a Congress in Your Community event from 12 to 1 p.m. at the Robert H. Gibson River Garden in Brattleboro. I want to hear your hopes and concerns for the new Congress and Administration. Hope you can stop by!  WHAT: Congress in Your Community town hall with Peter WHEN: Friday, March 31st from 12 to 1 p.m. WHERE: Robert H. Gibson River Garden, 157 Main Street, Brattleboro

Today is #EqualPayDay. Did you know that in almost any occupation a woman chooses she makes, on average, 80 cents for every dollar paid to a man in a similar occupation, and that the gender pay gap will not close until 2059? Unacceptable! When women succeed, America succeeds. On this Equal Pay Day, Congress should pass the Paycheck Fairness Act and end pay disparity once and for all. – Peter
Took this photo Friday in downtown Brattleboro. I couldn't have said it better! – Peter

Bashar al-Assad’s use of chemical weapons against the Syrian people is crime against humanity and a clear violation of international law. He is a war criminal who will be held accountable for his barbaric actions. The response last night by our military underscores the inescapable fact that the United States is already involved in the Syrian civil war. There are American boots on the ground in the region and our military is conducting regular air strikes. Yet, under our Constitution, only Congress has the power to declare war.  Until Monday, President Trump’s plan for Syria was to stay out of it. Just last week, his Secretary of State asserted that the fate of al-Assad was up to the Syrian people. Yesterday he implied that steps were underway that will lead to regime change in Syria.  President Trump has a constitutional obligation to submit to Congress his plan to defeat ISIS and stabilize Syria. Congress must get off the sidelines and do its job by debating and voting on his plan.

Yesterday, at the Sara Holbrook Community Center in Burlington, Peter kicked off a statewide tour to hear from Vermonters about the impact of President Trump’s budget proposal on their lives and communities. The Community Center is home to one of seven regional Vermont Head Start programs that collectively help 1,500 low-income children prepare for school. Under the Trump budget, Head Start could see its federal funding slashed by up to 18%. Today, Peter will be in St. Albans at NorthWest Family Foods.

Tomorrow, I’ll be hosting a Congress in Your Community town hall event from 7 to 8 p.m. at the Rutland Free Library. I want to hear your hopes and concerns for the new Congress and Administration. Hope you can stop by!  WHAT: Congress in Your Community town hall with Peter WHEN: Thursday, April 13th from 7 to 8 p.m. WHERE: Rutland Free Library, 10 Court Street, Rutland

Last week, The New York Times reported that Jared Kushner, President Donald J. Trump son-in-law and top adviser, omitted meetings with Russians when he sought security clearance that would give him access to the nation’s secrets.   This week, Congressman Don Beyer and Peter took action. The fact that Kushner is President Trump’s son-in-law does not place him above the law. Anyone else would face severe discipline for failing to disclose such meetings with foreign officials.
Catch Peter live on Vermont Public Radio's Vermont Edition at noon today.

Tomorrow, I’ll be hosting a Congress on Your Campus town hall event from 3:30 to 4:30 p.m. at the Moore Community Room on the campus of Lyndon State College. I want to hear from students and the LSC community about their hopes and concerns for the new Congress and Administration.  WHAT: Congress on Your Campus town hall with Peter WHEN: Thursday, April 20th from 3:30 to 4:30 p.m. WHERE: Moore Community Room, Lyndon State College

There is no doubt the world is warming, and at an alarming rate. The latest one, two, three, four and five year periods rank as the warmest in 122 years of record-keeping for the continental U.S., according to the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA). The science is clear, and ought to matter. President Donald J. Trump: this is the time to recommit to policies and accords like the Clean Power Plan and Paris Agreement that would lower the world's collective carbon footprint.

Peter spent the last two weeks on a statewide tour to hear from Vermonters about the impact President Donald J. Trump's budget would have on their lives and communities. Throughout the tour, he held press conferences, convened roundtables, and hosted town hall meetings. Check out the photos and their captions for more on what he was up to.

We will not go back to the days when Wall Street banks and credit card companies were ripping off Main Street merchants and consumers with unchecked debit card swipe fees. The reforms we passed in 2010 brought transparency and competition to the debit card system. Small businesses in Vermont and across the country, as well as their customers, have more money in their pockets due to the Durbin-Welch amendment. Senator Durbin and I will do everything we can to block this effort by big banks and credit card companies to claw back to their heyday of charging the highest debit card swipe fees in the world. – Peter

Over the last two weeks, I traveled throughout our state to hear from Vermonters about the impact President Donald J. Trump's budget would have on them and their communities. The message of this draconian budget is, simply put, ‘You’re on your own.’  I was inspired to hear their stories. – Peter

Today, the Trump Federal Communications Commission reversed course on the guarantee of a free and open internet, also known as net neutrality. Creating a fast lane on the internet for those who can afford it is a gift to internet service providers and bad for consumers and entrepreneurs. Make your voice heard during the public comment period: https://www.fcc.gov/ecfs/filings/express. Now is the time to speak up! It will make a difference. – Peter

Climate. Jobs. Justice. Combating climate change is the challenge of our time. Addressing it head-on will create jobs and strengthen our commitment to justice. Vermont has led the way.  Hope to see you at the Vermont People’s Climate March at the Vermont State House in Montpelier this Saturday at 1 PM.
“It’s not a question of vetting. It’s a question of did General Flynn break the law. And there is enormous evidence that he did.”

This afternoon, the House passed bipartisan legislation funding the federal government through the end of September. It protects important environmental programs and home heating assistance and increases funding for Pell grants, medical research, and the fight against opioid abuse. President Donald J. Trump’s proposal to build a wall on the southern border was not funded while Planned Parenthood was fully funded. While not perfect, it is a good compromise that meets many of the pressing needs of our country. – Peter

President Donald J. Trump won the election on the backs of hard working rural Americans. This so-called “repeal and replace” is a betrayal of rural America. I will vote HELL NO this afternoon! – Peter

Today was a dark day in the history of the United States Congress. By a vote of 217-213, the House of Representatives voted to take away health coverage from 24 million Americans, gut protections for people with preexisting conditions, raise premiums for those approaching retirement, take money from Medicare, and give a tax cut to the wealthiest Americans. I am hopeful the Senate will scrap this trash and start from scratch. Going forward, I will be working on bipartisan ideas to make the Affordable Care Act work better for Vermonters and all Americans. – Peter

Happy Green Up Day, Vermont! Started in 1970 by Governor Deane Davis, it's become one of Vermont's most cherished and important traditions. It's a day to take great pride in our state and in one another in what we can do in small ways to keep Vermont as beautiful as it is. – Peter

Tonight, I’ll be hosting a Congress in Your Community event from 5:30 to 6:30 p.m. at Study Hall on College Street in Burlington, Vermont. I want to hear your hopes and concerns for the new Congress and Administration. Hope you can stop by!  WHAT: Congress in Your Community WHEN: Tuesday May 9th at 5:30 p.m. WHERE: Study Hall, 209 College Street, Third Floor

President Trump’s sudden decision to fire James Comey has compromised the FBI’s ongoing investigation into the Russian government’s attempts to influence the outcome of our presidential election. The American people have a right to know what happened. It is in the best interest of the country and the President to quickly remove the dark cloud that has now descended over the Administration. The only credible way to do so is through the appointment of an independent prosecutor or a nonpartisan commission appointed by the Congress. We need to follow the facts and get to the bottom of this mess. – Peter

Congratulations to Jocelyn Pike of Lyndon Institute for winning the 36th Annual Congressional Art Competition! Her brilliant work, “Peru,” was selected from 161 student entries representing 35 Vermont high schools. It will be displayed for one year in the United States Capitol complex along with other winners from congressional districts across the country. I am amazed at the creativity of the many talented young artists across Vermont. A job well done to all participants. I’m looking forward to seeing Jocelyn’s artwork in the Capitol! – Peter
For #PoliceOfficersMemorialDay and #PoliceWeek2017, we honor the men and women who put their lives on the line every day to keep our communities safe. – Peter

Needless to say, there is a lot going on in Washington these days. One consequence of a daily stream of controversies is the overshadowing of attempts by the Trump Administration to roll back important consumer protections. On Thursday, the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) will vote on whether to initiate a process that will overturn its policy of a free and open internet. Doing so would allow internet service providers to create a fast lane on the internet for large corporate customers willing to pay a fee to move their content ahead of other internet users. This is bad for consumers, bad for entrepreneurs and bad for our democracy. If you support net neutrality, make your voice heard before Thursday’s FCC meeting. You can do so by completing an online FCC comment form at https://www.fcc.gov/ecfs/filings/express. (In the ‘Proceeding(s)’ box, enter ’17-108’ or ‘restoring internet freedom.’) – Peter

It seems as though every day there is another "breaking news" story coming out of Washington. Peter will be at his computer tomorrow evening at 5:30 p.m. for a live Q&A to take your questions, hear your concerns, and try to make sense of it all. Be sure to check his Facebook page tomorrow evening at 5:30 p.m. to join in!
Robert Mueller is a great choice. Time to get to the bottom of this mess. – Peter
Thanks everyone for joining. Gotta go. See you next time (yes, it really is me) Peter

The message to Americans in President Trump’s budget is clear: You are on your own. It doubles down on defense spending while gutting numerous programs that Vermonters depend on, including home heating assistance, Meals on Wheels, and student aid. And the savings from these draconian cuts will pay for tax cuts for the wealthiest Americans. This budget should be dead on arrival in Congress. I will do all I can to defeat it. – Peter

Every American should have affordable health care. Expanding Medicare to cover all Americans is how we can get it done. I'm proud to be an original cosponsor of #MedicareForAll legislation with Congressman John Conyers, Jr. and Senator Bernie Sanders. We have 100+ cosponsors in the House. The time has come. Momentum is building. – Peter
Sunrise over Mount Mansfield. Photo taken by Jan Ferris of Essex Junction.

Vermonters have always answered the call to duty. On this Memorial Day, and every day, we honor the tremendous sacrifice of fallen service members and thank those who put themselves in harm’s way to protect our country. May their stories be told and legacies be revered for generations to come. – Peter

Climate change is real and it threatens our environment, economy, and health. If President Donald J. Trump pulls out of the #ParisAgreement, he’ll unravel years of progress combating global warming and do irreversible harm to our planet. Combating climate change is the challenge of our time. American leadership is essential. We cannot afford to bury our heads in the sand.

This story is appalling. Earlier this year, while most in Congress were focused on stopping Speaker Ryan’s disastrous attempt to unravel the Affordable Care Act, Republican leaders and lobbyists secretly plotted an under-the-radar repeal of a major Federal Communications Commission rule protecting consumers' right to privacy on the internet. President Trump quietly signed it into law, allowing internet service providers to sell to marketers the data collected from your web browsing and app usage history. As Stephen Colbert said, "I guarantee you there is not one person, not one voter of any political stripe anywhere in America who asked for this.”   Let's make sure #netneutrality doesn't suffer the same fate. It’s time to speak up. Make sure the FCC knows that you favor a free and open internet by submitting a comment here: https://www.fcc.gov/ecfs/filings/express. (In the "Proceeding(s)" box, enter "17-108" or "restoring internet freedom.")
Wishing you and yours a happy Fourth of July! Hope everyone enjoys fireworks and time with family and friends. – Peter
Had a great time in Montpelier, Colchester, and Williston celebrating our nation's independence. Hope everyone enjoyed the beautiful weather! - Peter

I’ll be hosting a Congress in Your Community event tonight at 5:30 pm at Kingdom Taproom in St. Johnsbury. Hope you’ll have a chance to stop by and chat! – Peter   WHAT: Congress in Your Community WHEN: Thursday, July 6th at 5:30pm  WHERE: Kingdom Taproom, 397 Railroad Street, St. Johnsbury

Companies like Revision Military create jobs that help us build and sustain our rural economy and way of life. Yesterday, Peter was proud to join Senator Patrick Leahy and Governor Phil Scott in celebrating the company’s new contract, which will create good paying jobs in the Northeast Kingdom, and supply our troops overseas with high-quality helmets. Congratulations to this outstanding Vermont company, and thank you for investing in our communities!

Peter spent the last week travelling the state to celebrate the Fourth of July and hear from Vermonters. He met with business owners, held press conferences, and hosted a Congress in Your Community town hall meeting in St. Johnsbury. Check out the photos to see what he was up to.

President Trump thinks it’s a big deal to run a big corporation. Try running a school where you’ve got 23 different languages that are being spoken. I am so amazed at our teachers and educators and their ability to figure out how to do it and help these kids become good citizens. –Peter

I strongly believe the internet must remain open and accessible to all Americans. The Federal Communications Commission is poised to gut regulations in place that ensure net neutrality. Doing so would be bad for consumers and entrepreneurs and detrimental to our participatory democracy. Today, in a few minutes, I will join with other Members of Congress in a Facebook live stream to fight this misguided effort. You can watch here: https://www.facebook.com/energyandcommercedemocrats/. Regardless of your position on this issue, I encourage you to weigh in by completing the FCC’s online comment form at https://www.fcc.gov/ecfs/filings/express. (Note: In the ‘Proceeding(s)’ box, enter ’17-108’ or ‘restoring internet freedom.’) – #NetNeutrality – Peter

Rather than repealing or replacing a landmark law that has expanded quality health care to millions of Americans, the focus of Congress should be on improving the Affordable Care Act. We can build bipartisan consensus by taking steps to stabilize the individual market where 7 percent of Americans purchase health plans. Our commonsense reforms will help make health care affordable and accessible to all Americans. – Peter

The National Defense Authorization Act, passed by the House this morning, would increase Pentagon spending by $150 billion to an unprecedented level of $700 billion. The result will be a shift of federal resources from effective programs like student financial aid, home heating assistance, and clean environmental protection to an already bloated defense budget. I voted NO on this bad bill. I spoke up during the debate on the House floor:

This morning in the Statehouse, I joined Senator Patrick Leahy, U.S. Senator Bernie Sanders, Governor Phil Scott and Vermont legislative leaders to highlight the importance of federal Medicaid funding to Vermont, which is at risk under the GOP health care bill. This isn’t an abstract policy debate. This legislation would have devastating consequences for Vermonters and for our community hospitals. Rather than taking away health care coverage from Americans, Congress should be focused on improving the Affordable Care Act.

This week, Travel + Leisure released their list of the top 100 hotels in the world and two Vermont inns broke the top 30. Rabbit Hill Inn in Lower Waterford came in at #30 and Twin Farms in Barnard was ranked #15. Congratulations to both—very impressive!

The budget proposed this week by House GOP leaders sends a clear message to hard working Americans: ‘You are on your own.’ It doubles down on defense spending and tax cuts for the wealthiest Americans funded by slashing environment programs, food and heating assistance, housing programs, job training, and student financial aid. I will vigorously oppose this budget every step of the way.

Grateful to the Link Express for the quick, safe and comfortable ride from Burlington to Montpelier yesterday! Thanks to everyone at Green Mountain Transit who works so hard to make VT public transit operate efficiently.

Rather than repealing or replacing a landmark law that has expanded quality health care to millions of Americans, the focus of Congress should be on improving the Affordable Care Act. We can build bipartisan consensus by taking steps to stabilize the individual market, where premiums have skyrocketed. Today at LaValley Building Supply in West Lebanon, NH, Congresswoman Annie Kuster and I outlined our plan to do just that. Our commonsense reforms will help make health care more affordable and accessible to Vermonters and all Americans.–Peter

This is disgraceful. And as the Senate prepares to vote on yet another disastrous health care bill, it is a reminder of what taking away health coverage from Americans actually entails. It is time to improve the Affordable Care Act to make health care more affordable and accessible, not rip it away from millions in need.

President Donald J. Trump's abrupt decision to bar transgender individuals from military service is cruel, arbitrary, and goes against everything this country stands for. It is nothing less than a slap in the face to more than 15,000 transgender Americans currently serving in the military and 134,000 transgender veterans who put their lives on the line for our country around the world. With just three tweets, he weakened our military and the country it defends. Shameful.—Peter

Incredibly, the Pentagon wasted $28 million on licensing a camouflage pattern for Afghan army uniforms that replicates lush forests, even though most of Afghanistan is a desert. Yesterday, the House passed my amendment banning Pentagon spending on uniforms for the Afghan National Army. This is the same Pentagon that the Administration has proposed a budget increase of $55 billion.
Great to see Green Mountain Power recognized by The New York Times for their leadership in sustainability. Leading Vermont, leading the industry, leading the nation – congratulations!

I learned a lot today as I toured the city of Rutland , Vermont  with Police Chief Brian Kilcullen. I heard about the challenges and opportunities facing the city and the many great partnerships that make Rutland a great place to live and work. Thanks for the ride, Chief! –Peter

This was complicated, this was difficult, and there’s more ahead. It’s about a belief in the future, it’s about a belief in ourselves, and it’s about the ability to know that we can accomplish the most when we can work with other people. I can’t wait to bring some good Brandon dirt back to Washington, D.C.! – Peter
Catching the Local Motion bike ferry to South Hero on my afternoon ride on the Island Line Trail. It’s a beautiful day to be on the bike path! –Peter #VT

A big thanks to the summer interns in our Washington and Burlington offices! David, Ada, Eric, Cordelia, and Cooper worked hard for Vermonters all summer and learned a lot along the way. As David said, “This summer I had the opportunity to assist Congressman Welch’s staff at all points in the legislative process. I am grateful to have had this experience and fortunate to have gotten to know the Congressman and his staff. For anyone interested in government, this internship is for you! ”  If you are a college student or recent graduate interested in public service and the legislative process, an internship in our office is a great way to gain valuable experience and college credit. We are taking applications now for our Fall program. Click below for more information. The application window closes on August 25th! https://welch.house.gov/services/internships
Catch Peter live on Vermont Public Radio's Vermont Edition at noon today.
Thanks to all the Vermont Youth Conservation Corps members who are working hard this summer to keep our state beautiful! We are all grateful for your service to Vermont’s communities and land.

“Thousands of Vermonters have worked here. Thousands of patents and intellectual property created that has enhanced the world we lived in. And you and the people who came before you are part of it.” Yesterday, Peter was proud to join Senator Patrick Leahy and Governor Phil Scott to celebrate 60 years of making semiconductor chips in Vermont at the Global Foundries, Essex Junction site, which opened in 1957 as an IBM facility. Congratulations, and thank you for investing in our communities!
Meeting Haley and Lucas and their cows. Spent a great day at Addison County Fair and Field Days and even got to see Rosie’s Racing Pigs! - Peter

What happened is Charlottesville is tragic in lives lost and people injured, and inexcusable in the conduct of those who trafficked in the hate and intolerance that inspired it. There is no justification – none – for the conduct of the people involved. President Trump should condemn this conduct, not pretend there is an equivalency of actions between people who peaceably demonstrate and those who violently attack. Those who do threaten innocent Americans and threaten the foundation of our democracy itself. –Peter https://www.nytimes.com/2017/08/12/us/charlottesville-protest-white-nationalist.html?rref=collection%2Fsectioncollection%2Fus&action=click&contentCollection=us&region=rank&module=package&version=highlights&contentPlacement=1&pgtype=sectionfront

"No high political leader should condone political statements that are going to cause the erosion of rights and sowing the seeds of hatred against fellow citizens, and Donald Trump is very dangerously in the territory of doing that."

Prescription drug prices are out of control. Today Representative Elijah E. Cummings and I initiated an investigation to determine why drug companies are dramatically increasing their prices for drugs used to treat Multiple Sclerosis (MS), a devastating disease. No American should struggle to pay for lifesaving medicine especially when drug companies increase prices without warning, cause, or justification. –Peter

I listened carefully to the president tonight and have a lot of questions about his decision to continue our military’s engagement in the nearly 17-year war in Afghanistan. I am deeply concerned about committing more American troops to an unwinnable conflict. Is this new strategy worthy of the sacrifice we will ask of our soldiers and their families? Will committing more troops achieve the president’s objectives?  What will the role of our allies be, especially those in the region with the most at stake? It’s time for Congress to get off the sidelines and debate the president’s plan, and vote on it up or down. What questions do you have about his plan? –Peter

Combating climate change is the challenge of our time. There is no denying that it’s threatening our environment, our economy, and our health. American leadership is essential. We cannot afford to wait.

On this the 6th anniversary of Tropical Storm Irene slamming into Vermont, I know all Vermonters are concerned about the well-being of Texans who are enduring the devastation being inflicted by Hurricane Harvey. We wish them well and are grateful for the heroic work of first responders and National Guard troops involved in ongoing rescue operations. If you would like to help victims of this storm, click here: https://www.redcross.org/donate/hurricane-harvey —Peter
Best of luck to all Vermont students going back to school this week. Have a great school year! –Peter
Nothing better than a maple creemee on warm summer day! Had a great time yesterday at The Champlain Valley Fair.

As we head out today for shopping trips, barbecues and bike rides with family and friends, let's remember to celebrate the strength and courage of American workers, their contributions to our economy, and their struggle over the years to improve working conditions and earn a fair wage. In a challenging era of unemployment, underemployment and stagnated wages, there are clearly miles to go before every worker achieves the economic security, dignity, and respect they deserve. – Peter #LaborDay

Donald J. Trump's cruel decision to end DACA strikes at the very heart of the American Dream. 800,000 hardworking, law-abiding young people in communities across Vermont and America now face the threat of deportation from the only country they have ever known. Congress must reverse this heartless decision.

This morning I had the opportunity to meet in the Capitol with several DREAMers who are now at risk of being deported due to the President’s cruel decision on DACA. I was inspired by their courage and determination in the face of adversity and uncertainty. I humbly stand with them and will do all I can to pass the DREAM Act to ensure these young people, including 42 in Vermont, will continue their contributions to their communities and our nation. –Peter

Lake Champlain is the environmental crown jewel of our region. It is central to our cultural heritage and natural history, and an invaluable recreational and economic resource. My bipartisan amendment, approved by the House last evening, restores $4.4 million in fiscal year 2018 funding for the Lake Champlain Basin Program. It is essential that this great lake be protected and preserved for generations to come.

We now know that weeks ago, hackers stole the private data of millions of Americans from the credit reporting company, Equifax. This unprecedented theft of consumers’ personal information raises a lot of questions, not the least of which is why three executives of the company sold nearly $2 million in company stock just days after the data breach, and weeks before the company notified the public. The company and its executives should be held accountable. And Congress should pass a data security law that protects consumers in the future.  In the meantime, here are some steps you can take to protect your identity in the wake of this data breach:

I wish President Trump was with me yesterday at The Robert Larner, M.D. College of Medicine at The University of Vermont to hear the inspiring and poignant story of first year medical student Juan Conde. Juan is a Dreamer who came to this country when he was 9 years old. Against all odds, he earned a PhD in biochemistry.   DACA opened the door to medical school for him. Inspired by the tragic death of his mother from cancer, Juan hopes to one day find a cure to cancer and specialize in oncology. I am determined to help Juan and 800,000 Dreamers, including 42 in Vermont, remain in this country. We need their example, and we need the benefit of their contributions.—Peter

What a pleasure it was to meet today with Donna Carpenter of Burton Snowboards and an inspiring group of professional winter athletes, ski resort leaders, and outdoor industry experts. They were on Capitol Hill with Protect Our Winters to push for Congressional action on climate change. Their message was simple: “Protect our winters so we can protect our game.” Thank you for leading the charge on such an important issue! – Peter

On Thursday of this week, NH Congresswoman Annie Kuster and I will jointly host a town hall meeting for Upper Valley residents from 7 to 8 p.m. at the Richmond Middle School in Hanover. Hope you can stop by! –Peter   WHAT: Upper Valley Town Hall with Rep. Welch and Rep. Kuster  WHEN: Thursday, September 21st from 7 to 8 p.m.  WHERE: Richmond Middle School, 63 Lyme Road, Hanover, NH

Vermont’s community hospitals provide high quality care in rural communities across our state. A loophole in the law is allowing allowing drug companies to charge them higher prices for prescription drugs. As a result, they are struggling to afford life-saving drugs to treat rare diseases. I’ve introduced legislation to close the loophole and ensure that our community hospitals continue delivering outstanding care to Vermonters.—Peter

C-SPAN paid a visit to the Queen City yesterday as part of their Cities Tour. Peter talked about Vermont’s history of activism and civic participation, from being the first state to abolish slavery to our Town Meeting Day tradition each March. And they promised to try a maple creemee while they’re here! Look for the segment to air in November.
Shanah Tovah to all who are celebrating Rosh Hashanah in Vermont and around the world!—Peter
Visited Brattleboro Development Credit Corporation Ecovation Hub yesterday: great to see Windham County leaders charting a sustainable regional economy—Peter
Thanks to all who joined Congresswoman Annie Kuster and me at our town hall meeting last night. These are tumultuous times, but we will persevere and gain strength from each other. – Peter

More than three million American citizens are suffering under horrendous conditions in Puerto Rico – no power, no cell phone service or internet access, damaged homes, and limited supplies of food and water. The people of Puerto Rico are desperate. President Trump should send every available resource to the island, including the military. And Congress should fund a massive recovery program. Time is of the essence.

Congrats to Vermont Principal of the Year, Steve Perrin from Brattleboro Union High School. From his outstanding work on the Collegiate High School dual credit program to his collaborative style with teachers and peers, Steve has been a strong voice for education in Brattleboro and statewide. This is a well-deserved recognition of his leadership. —Peter

This week, I had the privilege to visit with members of the United Mine Workers of America. It was just two years ago this weekend that I carpooled to West Virginia with my friend, David McKinley to tour coal country and meet with coal miners in his district. We went deep into a mine where I saw firsthand the tough job these folks have, enduring daily risks to health and safety. Through no fault of their own, their jobs are now at risk and their communities are struggling. For generations, they have risked their lives to keep our homes warm, lights on, and factories powered. While there is deep division in Congress on the causes of climate change, we should all be able to agree that America has a moral obligation to ensure these workers have good pensions, health care, and job training to transition to meaningful careers in other industries.—Peter

High school seniors considering going to college next year should keep in mind that planning ahead is a key ingredient for success. The Free Application for Federal Student Aid (FAFSA), which provides grants and low-interest loans to college students, opens to all applicants today. In addition, students have the option of applying for grants and loans through the Vermont Student Assistance Corporation (VSAC), which does an outstanding job of helping Vermont students finance their college education.

Finding quality, affordable child care should not be keeping parents up at night. But in Vermont and across the country, child care remains one of the biggest challenges for working families. This morning at Trinity Children’s Center in Burlington, I announced legislation that will provide much needed relief to families struggling to find and pay for quality child care. The Child Care for Working Families Act will ensure that working Vermonters are able to find and pay for quality child care.—Peter

I know I join all Vermonters in reacting with horror and utter disbelief to the slaughter of innocent life in Las Vegas early this morning. It’s hard for any of us to imagine the sheer terror experienced by concertgoers running for their lives, unsure of the depraved shooter’s location. It’s hard to imagine the inconsolable grief being experienced by the families of the victims. And it’s hard to fathom the inaction of Congress in the face of so many mass shootings in this country. What will it take to pass common sense gun laws that take guns out of the hands of people who should not have them? We pray for those injured and killed. And we are grateful yet again for the brave first responders who stopped the shooter and selflessly came to the aid of hundreds of innocent victims.—Peter
Every fall foliage season brings leaf peepers to Vermont from across the country and around the world to take in our breathtaking views. Check out this stunning aerial footage of Jay, Vermont.

Climate change is a serious threat to our planet, our economy, our livelihoods, and our health. It is simply astonishing that, in the face of overwhelming scientific evidence, President Trump and Congressional leaders have chosen to bury their heads in the sands of denial. Gutting the Clean Power Plan, on the heels of pulling out of the Paris Climate Accord, will deal a serious blow to our environment and our reputation around the world.

This story defines Big Pharma chutzpah. In a brazen scheme to extend its monopoly pricing power over the eye drug Restatis, Allergan transferred its patents on the drug, along with a cash payment of $13.75 million, to a Native American tribe in a bid to bypass U.S patent laws. Along with three House colleagues I am leading a bipartisan investigation and will soon introduce legislation to make this tactic illegal:

The opioid crisis is ravaging communities in Vermont and across the country. Watch LIVE now as Peter shares Vermont’s experience and offers proposals to help the first responders, local law enforcement, health care providers, and treatment facilities on the front lines of this public health emergency.

The opioid crisis is ravaging communities in Vermont and across the country. Watch LIVE now as Peter shares Vermont’s experience and offers proposals to help the first responders, local law enforcement, health care providers, and treatment facilities on the front lines of this public health emergency.

The opioid crisis is ravaging communities in Vermont and across the country. Today, Peter testified before a key House subcommittee about Vermont’s experience with the epidemic. He outlined a four-part plan to help first responders, local law enforcement, health care providers, and treatment facilities on the front lines of this public health emergency. “This affects us all, I mean it’s heartbreaking,” he said. “It doesn’t matter if it is a red district or a blue district. It doesn’t matter what your view is on the size and scope of government. Our job in Congress is to come up with policies that will help people help themselves.”
Not even a fair fight, especially if it’s pure Vermont maple, the best in the world!
Thanks to all Vermont farmers who work year round from dawn to dusk on over 7,000 farms. Happy National Farmers’ Day. We appreciate all you do.—Peter

Donald J. Trump's decision to cut off payments that defray out of pocket costs for low income Americans is stunning, reckless, and cruel. After failing to convince Congress to repeal the Affordable Care Act, he is now openly sabotaging it, which will raise the premiums of hardworking Americans by 20 percent. He is also undermining bipartisan discussions well underway in Congress to make much needed improvements to the law. I hope this irresponsible decision is overturned by the courts. In the meantime, Congress should move forward with making the Affordable Care Act work better for working families. - Peter

Peter didn’t take any new friends home from The Quirky Pet yesterday, but he did get to explore an amazing Vermont business that sells only American-made products. Supporting small businesses like Quirky Pet keeps our downtowns vibrant and our communities strong.

Weighing in at 1,800 pounds and producing close to 150 pounds of milk per day, Enosburg’s Blexy the bovine was recently named Supreme Champion of the World Dairy Expo. Congratulations to her co-owners Sharyn and Tim Abbott of Borderview Genetics. Very impressive!

Landing a job after high school requires good education and training. Earlier this week, I joined Vermont Student Assistance Corporation (VSAC) and Winooski High School students to announce an exciting new mentorship program for seniors at the school. The entire class will receive individualized counseling as they explore education and training programs that meet their needs. I’m looking forward to hearing about the paths they choose and their future success! - Peter

NPR’s How I Built This explores Jake and Donna Carpenter’s fascinating journey creating and expanding Vermont’s Burton Snowboards. Jake started making snowboards with whittled stacks of wood at a barn in Londonderry at the age of 23. Today Burton is the largest snowboard brand in the world. I am pleased to showcase one of their originals alongside other Vermont products in our DC office!

Joined by Vermont Representative Mary Morrissey, I was honored on Friday to spend time with veterans at the The Vermont Veterans' Home in Bennington. Their courage and determination was inspiring. Thank you for your service and sacrifice, and for taking the time to share your stories (and basketball technique).  - Peter

Astonishingly, in a boon for Big Pharma, the federal government is prohibited by law from using its bulk purchasing power to negotiate lower drug prices for seniors in the Medicare Part D program. Paying retail drug prices for wholesale purchases is absurd. Today, along with U.S. Senator Bernie Sanders and other colleagues, I introduced legislation that will end this gift to drug companies and save seniors and taxpayers billions of dollars. –Peter

President Trump’s announcement falls far short of what is needed to tackle the opioid epidemic ravaging communities in Vermont and across the nation. While his remarks were on target, he failed to provide the resources needed by those on the front lines of this crisis. First responders, law enforcement agencies, health care providers, treatment facilities, and service organizations desperately need help to pay for prevention and treatment initiatives. Delivering a speech will not make this crisis go away. What is needed is strong leadership and funding from the federal government and a robust partnership with governors, mayors, and public health professionals that meets this challenge head on. –Peter

Today’s indictments mark the beginning of the American people finally getting a definitive answer to the central question of what then-candidate Donald Trump and his associates knew about Russian efforts to influence the outcome of our 2016 election, and to what extent, if any, they colluded in this sinister effort.   After reading news accounts of the charges against Mr. Manafort, I am mystified at how Donald Trump could have hired an individual with such a shady background as his top campaign official. It is clear that Mr. Mueller is methodically and systematically following the facts, as he should. I remain confident he will get to the bottom of this mess and hold accountable anyone who broke the law. –Peter

Many thanks to road crews, utility line workers, law enforcement, and first responders working around the clock to clear roads, restore power and keep us all safe. As always, you are doing an incredible job in difficult conditions. Thank you! – Peter

This year’s open enrollment period for health insurance starts tomorrow, November 1st, and runs through December 15th. Make sure to get covered and choose a plan that works best for you and your family.

Donald J. Trump's tax plan is bad for the middle class and bad for America. It gives a tax break to the wealthiest Americans and pays for it by adding a whopping $1.5 trillion to the nation’s credit card.  And it rewards corporations that move jobs overseas which will result in the loss of good American jobs. The bill was written in secret, with the intent of ramming it through Congress without a single public hearing. The federal tax code is outdated and riddled with loopholes and it needs to be reformed.  The focus of Congress should be on rewriting our tax code to provide growth and relief to the middle class. This bill does the opposite. –Peter

Vermonters should not have to choose between heating their homes and feeding their families. The Low Income Home Energy Assistance Program (LIHEAP) is a vital lifeline for Vermonters struggling to get by during the cold winter months. At the request of the Vermont Congressional Delegation, federal officials have released to Vermont $16.9 million in home heating assistance funding. Vermonters seeking assistance can call 1-800-479-6151 or visit the website of the Department of Children and Families here:

As Congress prepares to write a new Farm Bill, Peter is hosting a series of roundtable discussions with farmers across Vermont. As he told a group of Champlain Valley specialty crop farmers gathered at Happy Valley Orchard in Middlebury last week, “If we come together and share priorities, we can have enormous influence on what the ultimate shape of the Farm Bill is.” What are your priorities for improving the Farm Bill? Please share them with Peter by commenting below.

On Veterans Day, and every day, we honor the men and women who answered the call of duty and put their lives on the line in service of our country around the world. Those of us who have never worn a uniform are forever indebted to those who have. To all our veterans and their families—thank you for your service and sacrifice. You are among the best our nation has to offer. –Peter   P.S. If you are a veteran experiencing difficulty with your veterans benefits, please call my office at 802-652-2450. We will make every effort to help you.

Donald J. Trump has railed against the pharmaceutical industry ‘getting away with murder’ on drug prices. He promised the American people he would bring skyrocketing drug prices ‘way, way, way, down.’ But when given the chance to put his money where his mouth is, he brazenly nominated a former pharmaceutical executive to lead the agency charged with managing prescription drug costs. Instead of draining the swamp, he has set the fox to guard the henhouse.—Peter

In June, Donald Trump declared his intention to withdraw from the Paris Climate Accord. He walked away from the greatest challenge of our time. But in the absence of his leadership, states, businesses and individuals across the country have taken up the mantle by committing to upholding the goals set by the Paris Agreement. They are still in and so am I.  – Peter

From Peter’s remarks this afternoon during House debate on the Trump-Ryan tax bill:  “If you asked 435 members of Congress if they want to raise taxes on students, the answer for 435 members would be ‘No!’ This bill was written by and for the donor class. Let’s defeat this bill and stand up for the middle class.”

Calling all college students interested in public service and the legislative process! An internship in Peter’s Vermont or Washington, D.C. offices is a great way to gain valuable experience and college credit. We are taking applications now for our spring internship program. Click below for more information. The application window closes on December 1st! https://welch.house.gov/services/internships

Over the past week as I've visited food shelves and meal delivery programs, I've been so touched by the charitable heart of Vermonters. So many people will enjoy Thanksgiving meals today thanks to these efforts. I hope you and your family have a very happy Thanksgiving.—Peter

A free and open internet is essential to the free flow of ideas, creativity, participatory democracy, and commerce. This proposal is a wholesale abandonment of the FCC's core responsibility to protect the interests of consumers and an early Christmas present to big telecom companies, who will be able to pick and choose who gets access to the internet and at what speed. I hope the courts overturn this misguided anti-consumer policy. - Peter
Congratulations to Burke Mountain Academy alum Mikaela Shiffrin on another first place finish at the Killington World Cup. 26 World Cup slalom wins at 22 years old! Incredible.

This is not tax reform. It’s a tax cut for the wealthiest Americans that will add a whopping $1.5 trillion to the nation’s credit card. The President and Republican leaders cannot hide the fact that both the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office and the Joint Committee on Taxation found that middle income Americans will end up paying higher taxes if this bill becomes law.
Another great example of Vermont communities paving the way with green technology. Kudos to Saint Albans Town Educational Center, and to SunCommon for installing 2,089 panels!

Too often, drug companies game the system to maximize corporate profits at the expense of consumers and taxpayers. They need to be held accountable. Elizabeth Warren and I introduced a bill that will do just that by requiring large drug companies caught breaking the law to reinvest a percentage of their profits into medical research at the National Institutes of Health (NIH) and U.S. Food and Drug Administration. Our legislation will make it harder for drug companies to profit from breaking the law while funding critical medical research at no taxpayer expense.
Since the days of Teddy Roosevelt, protecting and preserving precious public lands has been a bedrock and nonpartisan American ideal. I hope the courts overturn this short-sighted decision.—Peter

President Trump’s reckless decision to unilaterally recognize Jerusalem as the capital of Israel undermines decades of bipartisan American efforts to broker a lasting peace in the Middle East. His focus should be on brokering a two-state solution that guarantees Israel’s existence as a Jewish, democratic, and secure state, and provides the Palestinians a just and stable future. Instead, this needlessly provocative decision damages prospects for a peaceful resolution to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict and jeopardizes the security of the United States and Israel.—Peter

Got health care? If you need a health plan, don’t miss the opportunity to sign up during open enrollment for Vermont Health Connect! You have until December 15th to pick a plan that works best for you and your family.  To enroll, visit VermontHealthConnect.org or call 855-899-9600. Spread the word!
Only three days left to get covered!
Have a question for Peter? Join him right here on Facebook for a Q&A session today at 5:45 PM. He’ll be at his computer answering your questions live!

Have a question or a suggestion for me? I’m at my desk and ready to answer your questions live!  Thank you so much. I enjoyed this.. Everyone....have a nice holiday season. We are all lucky to be Vermonters. Peter

Today’s Federal Communications Commission decision to gut net neutrality is a disaster for consumers and an early Christmas present to big broadband companies who can now pick and choose who gets access to the internet and at what speed. I will soon introduce legislation to reverse this horrible decision so that the internet remains open and accessible to all Americans. -- Peter

Companies like Columbia Forest Products create jobs that help us build and sustain our rural way of life. For years, the company and its employees have been reeling from subsidized and illegal competition from China. Peter was proud to advocate for a level playing field for this outstanding company, which will create more good-paying jobs in the Northeast Kingdom.

This is not tax reform. This is a tax cut for the donor class, sprinkled with tiny and temporary benefits for the middle class, which will be paid for by our children and grandchildren. Unconscionable.
Wishing you light, hope, and peace in the coming year. Happy holidays to you and your loved ones. –Peter

I am deeply concerned about orchestrated efforts to discredit and disrupt the investigation of Special Counsel Robert Mueller. Mr. Mueller is an honest and honorable man of the utmost integrity. He is widely respected in law enforcement circles. And, he also happens to be a Republican. Today, I joined 171 of my House colleagues in sending a letter to the Department of Justice demanding that Mueller be allowed to continue his investigation unfettered by political influence or threats to his authority. The rule of law is the founding principle of our nation.  No one is above the law, including President Trump.—Peter
